Additionally, there's the idea of the "Golden Bull," which was a decree by King Andrew II of Hungary in 1222. So, putting this all together, it seems that in the Kingdom of Hungary, especially during the medieval period, landowners or nobles did have a role in electing their rulers, particularly when there was no clear heir. However, as the monarchy became more established, the election process might have been more of a formality or influenced by dynastic marriages and alliances. Thus, landowners did not elect their rulers during the later periods of the kingdom.
